document.text: Traffic channelization and new signing at the busy intersection of US Route 460 and Route 24 west of Appomattox have been accom panied by a 44 per cent reduction in traffic accidents and a 100 per cent cut in fatalities, the State Highway Department repotred to day. A report just completed by the Departments accident study, section showed that during the 22 months prior to the traffic engineering changes, nine accidents were re ported. One person was killed and three were injured. Since the changes which were completed in May, 1955, under the direction of District Engineer J. H. Phillips, of Lynchburg, only five accidents have been reported. J. P. Mills, Jr., traffic and plan ning engineer for the Department, said that although there was no de crease in the number of people in jured in the after study period, there were 38 pen cent fewer acci dents involving property damage. He noted also that during the per iod of the study, average daily traffic increased almost 18 per cent. Investigations made in 1954 by the Highway Department and the State Police showed the necessity of eliminating the Y-shaped inter section of the two heavily travel ed routes, Mills said. This was done by directing westbound traffic on Route 460 onto old Route 26, which intersects Route 460 from the north at a right angle. That por tion of Route 460 between Routes 24 and 26 is now one-way for easibound traffic. Improvements included installa tion of oversize guide and destina tion- signs and widening a short section of pavement on the old road. The total cost of the im provements was 1,430.
